title: Home
text:
I am a Lecturer in Statistics and Data Science (US equivalent: Asst. Professor) at the University of New South Wales, Sydney.
Contact: kristen.hunter [at] unsw.edu.au
I am an applied and methodological statistician with particular expertise in causal inference. I am actively seeking collaborative projects related to environmental policy and climate change.

title: Research
text:
Research expertise and interest
My methodological expertise mainly lies is in causal inference: the design and analysis of experiments and observational studies. I am also interested in applied Bayesian analysis and statistical software. Applications of my research have included healthcare, genetics, education, energy, and basic science.
My future research agenda is to apply causal inference methods to problems in environmental science, policy, and climate change. I am actively seeking projects in this area. If you would like to collaborate, please reach out. I am eager to work with quantitative researchers, scientists, engineers, policy makers, or others who have problems where I can contribute statistical expertise.


Works in progress

D. Hsu, K. Hunter, G. Cartwright, L. Garcia, M. Li, K. Shaw, M. Sutton, Y. Yin. Relative influences on regulator approval of energy utility rates. Submitted.
K. Hunter, J. Gagnon-Bartsch. Confounding and population stratification in genetics studies. Work in progress.



Preprints

N. Pashley, K. Hunter, K. McKeough, T. Dasgupta, D. Rubin. (2022). Causal inference from treatment-control studies having an additional factor with unknown assignment mechanism. Preprint. https://arxiv.org/abs/2202.03533.
K. Hunter, K. Koenig, M.A. Bind. (2021). Conceptualizing experimental controls using the potential outcomes framework. Preprint. https://arxiv.org/abs/2104.10302.



Publications

K. Hunter, L. Miratrix, K. Porter. (2024). PUMP: Estimating power, minimum detectable effect size, and sample size when adjusting for multiple outcomes in multi-level experiments. Journal of Statistical Software, 108(6). https://doi.org/10.18637/jss.v108.i06.
K. Hunter, M. Glickman, L. Campos. (2022). Inferring medication adherence from time-varying health measures. Statistics in Medicine, 41(12). https://doi.org/10.1002/sim.9351.
L. Campos, M. Glickman, K. Hunter. (2021). Measuring effects of medication adherence on near-term time-varying health outcomes using marginal Bayesian dynamic linear models. Biostatistics, 22(3). https://doi.org/10.1093/biostatistics/kxz059.

title: Software
text:
PUMP
The PUMP R package allows a user to estimate power for multi-level experiments with multiple outcomes. The package extends existing power calculation software to take into account multiple testing adjustments (such as Bonferroni or Benjamini-Hochberg adjustments, among others). It also estimates minimum detectable effect size (MDES) and sample size requirements.
More information:

PUMP is available on CRAN. The CRAN site contains vignettes on using the package.
For source code and further details, see the github site.
For a full package description, including a detailed technical appendix, see arXiv.
For users not familiar with R, see the shiny app
For a presentation about PUMP, see these slides.
